April 19, 1992: Fiction
THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law
student seeks to discover the truth about the murder of two Supreme Court justices.
RISING SUN, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $22.) The mysterious death of a young
woman leads to an investigation in which technology and the American-Japanese
rivalry play major roles.
THE ELF QUEEN OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $22.) The
third volume in a series about a fantasy land.
DISNEY'S BEAUTY AND THE BEAST. (Gallery Books/Penguin USA, $6.98.) A
retelling of the classic fairy tale in words and pictures.
THE ROAD TO OMAHA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $23.95.) A retired
general and a lawyer scheme to take possession of the state of Nebraska on behalf
of an obscure Indian tribe.
VOX, by Nicholson Baker. (Random House, $15.) A man and a woman learn about
each other through a telephone conversation on an "adult party line."
PROBE, by Margaret Wander Bonanno. (Pocket, $18.95.) The crew of "Star Trek" 's
Enterprise confronts a force that threatens galactic peace.
ACTS OF FAITH, by Erich Segal. (Bantam, $23.) The stories of three Brooklyn
natives, one of whom rises high in the Roman Catholic hierarchy, two who break
with their traditional Jewish heritage.
SCARLETT, by Alexandra Ripley. (Warner, $24.95.) The sequel to "Gone With the
Wind."
OUTERBRIDGE REACH, by Robert Stone. (Ticknor & Fields, $21.95.) A man tries
to relieve the frustrations of his lifetime by participating in a solo sailing race.
TRIAL BY FIRE, by Harold Coyle. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) The United States
Army in a war against Mexico, a conflict marked by revolutionary forces, drug lords
and bungled intelligence.
SILENT PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $21.95.) A retired cop and a New York
policewoman join hands to track down an escaped serial killer.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) Verse and
pictures.
GRIFFIN & SABINE, by Nick Bantock. (Chronicle Books, $16.95.) The romance of
an artist and a secret admirer, told through illustrated cards and letters.
JAZZ, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $21.) A couple in the Harlem of the 1920's learn

Non-Fiction
REVOLUTION FROM WITHIN, by Gloria Steinem. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The
reflections of a feminist on the struggle to achieve self-esteem.
BACKLASH, by Susan Faludi. (Crown, $24.) A journalist contends that the media
and political groups are staging a war against women's rights.
DOUBLE CROSS, by Sam Giancana and Chuck Giancana. (Warner, $22.95.)
Two relatives of the late Sam Giancana recall his life in the Mafia.
ROGUE WARRIOR, by Richard Marcinko with John Weisman. (Pocket, $22.) The
memoirs of the retired commander of a counterterrorist unit.
BROTHER EAGLE, SISTER SKY: A Message From Chief Seattle, illustrated by
Susan Jeffers. (Dial, $14.95.) An environmental warning.
DEN OF THIEVES, by James B. Stewart. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) How four men
plundered and created havoc on Wall Street.
THE DISUNITING OF AMERICA, by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. (Norton, $14.95.) A
historian considers the effects that the current emphasis on ethnicity is having on
our society.
REINVENTING GOVERNMENT, by David Osborne and Ted Gaebler.
(Patrick/Addison-Wesley, $22.95.) How every level of government can be
restructured to operate more efficiently.
UNTO THE SONS, by Gay Talese. (Knopf, $25.) A journalist traces his heritage
through three generations, from Italy to Ocean City, N.J.
EARTH IN THE BALANCE, by Al Gore. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The
Tennessee Senator discusses factors affecting the environment.
THE TEXAS CONNECTION, by Craig I. Zirbel. (Texas Connection/Ingram,
$21.95.) An attorney says L.B.J. was involved in the death of J.F.K.
MOLLY IVINS CAN'T SAY THAT, CAN SHE? by Molly Ivins. (Random House,
$23.) Essays about the current political and cultural scene.
TOUJOURS PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The charms of rustic
France, as savored by a London advertising man who moved there.
THE OVERWORKED AMERICAN, by Juliet B. Schor. (Basic, $21.) The
diminishment of Americans' leisure time, and its consequences.
BARCELONA, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $27.50.) The story of the Spanish city
through 15 centuries.
